Award.AwardTitle: Collaborative Research: Threat Perception Following Mass Violence Events

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
Experiencing mass violence, terrorism, or other traumatic events can shape how individuals perceive and respond to their social world. Anecdotally, following extensive media coverage of mass violence events, many report perceiving objects, people, and situations as particularly threatening; and, as media coverage shifts to emphasize resilience and community cohesion, this hypervigilance for threats seems to dissipate. Karen Quigley (Northeastern University), Yu-Ru Lin (University of Pittsburgh) and their collaborators will empirically test how emotionally potent media coverage of a real-world threat alters threat perception (i.e., the perception of a potentially harmful event, situation or stimulus as present or imminent). Specifically, they will test the hypothesis that media coverage focusing on death and destruction caused by a serious real-world threat event will have a more detrimental impact on subsequent threat perception than media coverage of the same event that focuses on people's heroic responses to the threat. This work could reveal potential harmful real-world consequences of emotionally potent media reporting of a terrorism event as well as suggest methods for alleviating such effects (e.g., by reporting on positive responses to such tragedies, like the heroics of first responders). This work will also help characterize the types of individuals who are at greatest risk of altered threat perception after a mass violence or terrorism event or when media attention to such events increases.

This project will examine the effects of real-world mass violence on threat perception among members of an affected community using multiple threat perception paradigms in the laboratory. A longitudinal study will be used to assess changes in threat perception before, during and after renewed media coverage near an upcoming anniversary of the Boston Marathon bombings, a potent real-world mass violence event that killed three and injured more than 250. The investigators will utilize novel media tracking measures to assess changes in exposure to media coverage of the bombings and threat-related events at both the community-wide and individual level. Specifically, the research will examine changes in threat perception as a result of (1) naturally-occurring changes in participants' exposure to actual media coverage of the Boston Marathon bombings near an upcoming anniversary of the tragedy and (2) in-lab exposure to media-style vignettes about the bombings that are designed to specifically activate negative or positive concepts related to the tragedy. A second, cross-sectional study will examine responses to physical threats (i.e., guns) and social threats (i.e., scowling faces) shown outside of conscious awareness. This will test whether exposure and affective framing can influence the conscious detectability of physical and social threats. Taken together, this research will provide a better understanding of how real-world mass violence and the media response to it can influence basic perceptual mechanisms that underlie changes in every day judgments and behaviors among members of the affected communities.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over the recent past, it has become apparent that many of the deleterious consequences of exposure to mass violence are augmented by widespread media coverage of such incidents. Independent of any direct exposure to the actual event, greater media exposure to terrorism and mass violence may negatively impact mental and physical health, including increased trauma-related symptoms and poorer cardiovascular health outcomes. To date, however, assessments of media impact have relied almost exclusively on self-reported measures, and it remains unclear whether prior research results would be influenced by the potentially biased perceptions of media exposure, or whether the findings would apply to more general biological and perceptual processes. This work explores people’s perceptions at the time of the event, as well as their responses to the media coverage of the event. Our results can help planners, the media, government officials, and crisis managers plan for future terror and mass violence events – how to respond at the time, and how to mitigate longer-lasting negative impacts of such events.


In the wake of the Boston Marathon bombings on April 15, 2013, news outlets continuously reported on the tragedy and the on-going threat for weeks, and area residents were immersed in the stories and aftermath of the bombings. The bombing anniversaries directly following 2013 present a rare opportunity to examine how media coverage of a serious, real-world, community-wide threat acutely alters the perceptions of that terror or mass violence situation, as well as the longer-term perceptual and behavioral effects that normatively occur in those who are part of a threatened community, but not directly impacted.


For this project, we assembled an interdisciplinary team with expertise in psychological and neuroscience disciplines, as well as data science approaches to address the challenge of characterizing the media environment. We combined a computational linguistics methodology to analyze the massive amount of media data, with lab experiments involving behavioral, physiological, and self-reported measures to conduct this research. Over multiple anniversaries of the Boston Marathon bombings, we tracked and analyzed a variety of signals extracted from  a representative sampling of the community and their media environment, including participants' self-reported physical and emotional distress symptoms, their physiological reactivity to aversive stimuli, as well as the changes in both the extent of news coverage about the bombings and the affective tone of that news coverage. Our study offers the first empirical evidence that the effects of media coverage about terrorist-related events influence physiological activity, which has been closely related to mental health outcomes, following exposure to a traumatic event. Our findings also suggest that, even outside of reporting on incidents of mass violence, fluctuations in the seemingly more mundane affective content of daily news coverage can critically shape mental health and well-being.


This research made a significant contribution to the state-of-the-art understanding of how acts of mass violence and terrorism influence threat perception on the part of individuals – even if they weren’t directly involved in the event. Our findings have important and wide-ranging practical implications because the affective stimuli tested in our study are commonly used by media outlets to attract viewers and listeners, quite possibly impacting them in unintended and sometimes detrimental ways. Moreover, our findings could have an even greater impact on a wide variety of scientific disciplines, made possible through the access we provided to the media data collected for this project. This publically-available data allows the broader research community to examine the results of this project as well as to test new hypotheses using the data set. Perhaps most importantly, the societal scale media data collected around this event will become a valuable historical resource for further investigations in multiple domains, including terrorism communications and crisis management. 


Finally, this project has led to significant educational impacts through a cross-disciplinary and cross-institutional collaboration (between research groups from the University of Pittsburgh, PA, and Northeastern University, MA). It has provided opportunities for graduate and undergraduate students to get involved in interdisciplinary affective research and the big data science research process. Our research results and their implications have been disseminated to a wider audience through presentations at conferences and seminars across academia and industry, as well as stories in the news media.
